column4: What does the  " -o " attribute do in this command: sudo mount -t vboxsf -o uid=1000,gid=1000 $sharename /mnt/$sharename
im getting a message saying that this is an invalid option for mkdir
it was pulled off this page: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/VirtualBox/SharedFolders#Getting_VBoxLinuxAdditions.iso
isnt -o used for bind mounts like when you do a chroot ?
I believe so ... but the -t is whats giving me issues
so im not sure what thats supposed to be .. but mkdir doesnt have a " -t " option
-t sets the type of partititon like -t ntfs or -text4 ect.
type of filesystem on the partititon i should say
are you trying to mount a virtual box disk ?
Oh ok so im telling it that its a particular "vboxsf"
what page are you looking at ?
ctrl + F on the page for " sudo mount -t vboxsf  "
and thats the line of the mount which is giving me issues
vdfuse looks the best to me on there
